results.question: Why did the company exclude certain expenses from their calculation of Adjusted EBITDA?

results.markdown_table_response: We excluded certain expenses from our calculation of Adjusted EBITDA because we believe that these expenses are not indicative of our core operating performance and our results are not indicative of our core operating performance. We believe that, in some cases, these expenses are an indication that a company has been negatively impacted by one or more factors that are beyond its control. For example, our acquisition-related expense includes the amortization of the value of acquired assets (e.g., intellectual property, patents, trademarks, and goodwill), which is included as part of the acquisition-related expense. We believe that, in some cases, acquisitions may have been undertaken to make money and not to develop our core business, and in those cases, the acquisition-related expense will not be indicative of the core operating performance of the company.

results.question: What are the respective goodwill at 2018 and 2019?
results.markdown_table_response: The goodwill is a non-cash asset that represents the net book value of the business that is acquired and that is associated with the acquired assets. The goodwill is calculated by multiplying the total fair value of all the assets acquired by the product of the purchase price and the fair value of the total consideration transferred. The purchase price is the acquisition price less the fair value of the consideration that is not transferred. The fair value of the consideration is the value of the assets acquired multiplied by the amortization rate for the assets acquired and the cost of goods sold. The amortization rate is the percentage by which the fair value of the acquired assets is discounted to its fair value at the time of the acquisition. The acquisition price is the purchase price less the discount. The goodwill is the total of the goodwill of the acquired businesses and the goodwill of the business that is acquired. The goodwill is calculated by multiplying the total fair value of the acquired businesses by the amortization rate for the acquired businesses. The goodwill is the difference between the total fair value of the acquired businesses and the total fair value of the business that is acquired. The goodwill is the same at both 2018 and 2019.
